body:
### Problem

neovim crashed with
```corrupted unsorted chunks```
have this problem since couple of weeks ago
I open issue here because I assume that such a glibc error should not be invoked by any plugins.
If I'm wrong,please tell me,I'll close it.

### Steps to reproduce
place this into init.lua
```lua
local plugins_path = vim.fn.stdpath("data") .. "/lazy"

local function boot(name, url)
	local package_path = plugins_path .. "/" .. name
	if not vim.uv.fs_stat(package_path) then
		vim.fn.system({
			"git",
			"clone",
			"--filter=blob:none",
			"--single-branch",
			url,
			package_path,
		})
	end
	vim.opt.runtimepath:prepend(package_path)
end

boot("heirline.nvim", "https://github.com/rebelot/heirline.nvim.git")
boot("noice.nvim", "https://github.com/folke/noice.nvim.git")
boot("orgmode", "https://github.com/nvim-orgmode/orgmode.git")
boot("nui.nvim", "https://github.com/MunifTanjim/nui.nvim")

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd("VimEnter", {
	callback = function()
		require("noice").setup()
	end,
})

require("orgmode").setup()
require("heirline").setup({
	---@diagnostic disable-next-line: missing-fields
	statusline = {
		{
			{
				provider = function()
					require("orgmode.api").load()
				end,
			},
		},
	},
})
```
just run `nvim --clean -u init.lua` with 0.10.2 version,
It will download some grammar files and then crash
next time it will crash if you run `nvim --clean -u init.lua` with nightly/stable.
[backtrace.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17808666/backtrace.txt)

### Expected behavior

no crash

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

󰯉 nvim -v
NVIM v0.11.0-dev
Build type: Debug
LuaJIT 2.1.1713773202
Run "nvim -V1 -v" for more info

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no

### Operating system/version

nixos 25.05.20241115.5e4fbfb (Warbler)

### Terminal name/version

kitty 0.37.0

### $TERM environment variable

tmux-256color

### Installation

install from neovim-nightly-overlay

comment_data.body:
With the steps I get:
```
No parser for language "org"
```

> With the steps I get:
> 
> ```
> No parser for language "org"
> ```

It's a expected message if you are using nightly version...
try 0.10.2 first and then you can reproduce it with stable and nightly version
`corrupted unsorted chunks` does not appear in this codebase. What do you mean by "crash"? Where is the backtrace?

It has no response and then exit like this:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/77656743-d108-4775-970e-5be4cf7989ca)
[backtrace.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/17801851/backtrace.txt)
Please use a Debug build of Nvim (and its dependencies). Almost surely, this is the fault of the tree-sitter-org parser (which orgmode uses a forked version of).

> `corrupted unsorted chunks` does not appear in this codebase. What do you mean by "crash"? Where is the backtrace?

This is from glibc when heap meta-data is corrupted (usually by writing beyond the allocated buffer).

The issue template literally includes: "Please do not include a package manager in the reproduction steps.". Including a package manager makes it more difficult for developers to debug so please don't do it.

> I have tried my best to narrow it down in four plugins,can not cut down any plugins.

And definitely don't include `noice`. If, as you say, it is absolutely necessary to reproduce the crash, then this needs to be reported to `noice` (first).

Minimal steps also include the exact file you're opening, and step-by-step instructions starting with `nvim --clean -u minimal.lua` (never install test files into your actual stdpath!)

Why are you calling `require("orgmode.api").load()` as a statusline "provider". That function does not seem to return something that you would want in the statusline? In any case it calls `vim.wait()` which creates some kind of infinite event loop through `ui_refresh() -> ui_schedule_refresh()`  when called from a statusline callback expression. I guess we should avoid that.

Not sure what to do with it. Do you remember why [this](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18375/files#diff-23468d92a00f5092dcc849c220e58d33f524b6c36faa3b12a0e785bbd998ca87L188) change was made @bfredl? reverting that avoids the issue in this repro.

> Why are you calling `require("orgmode.api").load()` as a statusline "provider". That function does not seem to return something that you would want in the statusline? In any case it calls `vim.wait()` which creates some kind of infinite event loop through `ui_refresh() -> ui_schedule_refresh()` when called from a statusline callback expression. I guess we should avoid that. I want to show the number of `TODO`s today. the init.lua above removes any useless code.
My actual statusline config related to orgmode looks like this: ```lua Org = { { hl = 'Special', provider = function() local api = require 'orgmode.api' local files = api.load() local today_all = 0 local today_todo = 0 for _, file in ipairs(files) do for _, headline in ipairs(file.headlines) do if headline.deadline and headline.deadline:is_today() then if headline.todo_type == 'DONE' then today_todo = today_todo + 1 end today_all = 1 + today_all end end end return ' ' .. today_todo .. '/' .. today_all end, }, Space, { hl = 'DiagnosticError', provider = function() local api = require 'orgmode.api' local files = api.load() local undone = 0 for _, file in ipairs(files) do for _, headline in ipairs(file.headlines) do if headline.deadline and headline.deadline:is_past 'day' then if headline.todo_type ~= 'DONE' then undone = undone + 1 end end end end return ' ' .. undone end, }, update = { 'BufLeave', pattern = '*.org' }, } ```

> Not sure what to do with it. Do you remember why [this](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18375/files#diff-23468d92a00f5092dcc849c220e58d33f524b6c36faa3b12a0e785bbd998ca87L188) change was made [@bfredl](https://github.com/bfredl)? reverting that avoids the issue in this repro.

That... from the perspective of `ui_refresh()` doesn't change anything except for the name of function that `ui_refresh()` is calling. 

if "reverting this" doesn't mean bring back TUI thread then a new change is being proposed. That change needs to be made public, otherwise it is impossible to know what is being suggested.

Since `noice` uses FFI, it is conceivable that even the name change is breaking for them. (Which, to be clear, is on them, not us.)

Another reason why we should not accept bug reports involving `noice` unless they have been cleared by @folke first to make sure there's really a bug in Neovim.

> I open issue here because I assume that such a glibc error should not be invoked by any plugins.

If they use FFI, that assumption is wrong. (I mean, it still shouldn't be, but then it's the plugin's responsibility.)

On nightly, the only ffi thing noice uses is `textlock`, so I don't think this is caused by Noice.

```c
extern int textlock;
```
Then it should be possible to reproduce this without. We really need a more minimal reproducing example.

> That... from the perspective of `ui_refresh()` doesn't change anything except for the name of function that `ui_refresh()` is calling.
> 
> if "reverting this" doesn't mean bring back TUI thread then a new change is being proposed. That change needs to be made public, otherwise it is impossible to know what is being suggested.

No I didn't mean bring back TUI thread. The link includes line numbers which I was referring to. I.e. that commit replaced `deferred_refresh_event()->loop_schedule_fast()` with `ui_schedule_refresh()->multiqueue_put()`. The implications of which are not entirely clear to me but the mutexed version avoids the infinite event loop in this repro when reverting that small part of the commit. (I tried that out myself before looking through the commit history to try to understand the implications of the change and noticed it would be a partial revert of that commit.)

> . I.e. that commit replaced deferred_refresh_event()->loop_schedule_fast() with ui_schedule_refresh()->multiqueue_put()

No, for `ui_refresh()` it did not change anything like that. at all. It literally just changes the name of the function calling ` multiqueue_put(resize_events, ui_refresh_event, 0);`. That's it.

> the mutexed version avoids the infinite event loop in this repro when reverting that small part of the commit. 

There are `2**1611-1` ways you could partially revert this commit in a way which reverts the linked line plus some other subset of this commits line changes. The smallest possible of these which still compiles does not change anything except the name of a function. I will not be able to guess which of the other `2**1611-2` which is being suggested unless that is being actually specified.

Oh sorry, I see what you mean now. Reading diffs is hard I suppose. 
So the suggested diff isn't reverting anything but does avoid the issue, are there any problems with it?

(Also I was just looking to learn the implications of the suggested change, and thought to have stumbled upon a commit before which that was already used, but misinterpreted the diff. Just linked it for reference, not to "accuse" you of anything :) )
Thanks. that's a possible change, just a completely new workaround which not has been used before, at least not before or after the linked PR.

labels.description: We need minimal steps to reproduce the issue
labels.name: needs:repro

title: corrupted unsorted chunks
